territory.notes: Beginning in the 11th century, the Hausa developed centralized states in the northern portion of present-day Nigeria. These included Daura, Katsina, Kano, Zaria, Gobir, and, later, Kebbi. Each had a walled city, a market center, and a monarchical system of government. At times independent, the Hausa states were at different times and in different places brought under the control of the Songhai / Songhay Empire as well as the Bornu Empire to the east. Fulani Muslim scholar (mallam) Usman dan Fodio initiated a revolutionary jihad in the Hausa state of Gobir in 1804, leading by 1808 to an overthrow of most of the Hausa states in Hausaland (northern Nigeria), some of which had formerly been under the Empire of Bornu to the east. This brought the former Hausa states into the Fulani Empire by 1808, though it appears that some (in present-day northeastern Nigeria) may have remained under Bornu.
